awd_titl_txt: Isotopic Constraints on the Early History of the Earth
awd_abstract_narration: Recent advances in high precision mass spectrometry have                        made it possible to study the early history of the Earth (4-                    4.6 Ga ago) using the decay signature of the extinct nuclide                    146Sm.  146Sm was present at the beginning of solar system                      history with an abundance of only 0.25% of Sm.  Observable                      variations in the abundance of its daughter nuclide 142Nd                       record differentiation processes active only during the                         first 300 Ma of Earth history. By linking the short-lived                       146Sm-142Nd and long-lived 147Sm-143Nd chronometers into a                      "coupled" systematics, it is possible to precisely constrain                    the formation history of the Earth's primordial protocrust.                     The Hadean epoch (4.0-4.6 Ga) is the least well-known period                    in Earth history.  This project will map out a basic                            chronological outline of global geochemical differentiation.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: PRESIDENT AND FELLOWS OF HARVARD COLLEGE
